questions.text: Macrophages containing PAS positive granules and rod-shaped bacilli in small intestinal mucosa are found in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Whipple’s disease. Whipple’s disease is a rare systemic infection caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei. It predominantly affects the small intestine, where macrophages in the mucosa accumulate PAS-positive (periodic acid-Schiff positive) granules, which are indicative of the intracellular presence of the bacteria. These bacilli are typically rod-shaped and can be visualized with special stains, such as PAS. Whipple’s disease often presents with gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., malabsorption), along with systemic manifestations like joint pain, cardiac problems, and central nervous system involvement. The characteristic finding of macrophages containing PAS-positive granules and rod-shaped bacilli in the small intestinal mucosa is a diagnostic clue for this condition. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Agammaglobulinemia: Agammaglobulinemia is a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a lack of mature B cells and low levels of immunoglobulins (antibodies). This condition predisposes individuals to recurrent bacterial infections, but it does not involve PAS-positive macrophages or rod-shaped bacilli in the small intestine. Therefore, it is not associated with the findings described in the question. B. Tropical sprue: Tropical sprue is a malabsorption disorder that occurs in people living in or traveling to tropical regions. It is thought to be related to an infectious cause, but it is not associated with PAS-positive macrophages or rod-shaped bacilli. The disease primarily causes small bowel mucosal damage, leading to nutrient malabsorption, but without the characteristic findings of Whipple’s disease. D. Coeliac sprue: Coeliac disease (also called coeliac sprue) is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. It leads to villous atrophy in the small intestine, causing malabsorption. However, coeliac disease is not characterized by PAS-positive macrophages or rod-shaped bacilli in the intestinal mucosa. Instead, the characteristic findings are related to immune-mediated inflammation and tissue damage.

questions.text: 40-years-old immunocompromized patient presented with complaints of dysphagia. UGI scopy showed multiple ulcers in the distal esophagus. Biopsy from the esophagus showed the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cytomegalovirus. The clinical presentation of a 40-year-old immunocompromised patient with dysphagia and multiple ulcers in the distal esophagus, along with biopsy findings, is most consistent with Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV is a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS, organ transplant recipients, or those on immunosuppressive therapy. The characteristic finding of CMV infection in the esophagus is the presence of large, intranuclear inclusion bodies in the infected cells, often seen on histopathological examination. These inclusions are diagnostic for CMV infection and are typically associated with ulcerative lesions in the esophagus. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Candida: Candida infection can also cause esophageal ulcers and is another common infection in immunocompromised patients. However, Candida esophagitis typically presents with white plaques or pseudomembranes seen on endoscopy, rather than multiple deep ulcers. On biopsy, Candida would be identified by the presence of yeast cells and pseudohyphae, which is distinct from the intranuclear inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection. Therefore, Candida is less likely in this case, given the findings of ulcers and the clinical scenario. C. Herpes viral infection: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection can cause esophageal ulcers, especially in immunocompromised patients. HSV esophagitis is often characterized by vesicular lesions on endoscopy and multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusions on biopsy. However, the lesions in HSV infection tend to be smaller and more localized compared to CMV, and HSV typically causes vesicular ulcerations, not the large, deep ulcers that are characteristic of CMV. D. Eosinophilic esophagitis: Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is an inflammatory condition that is characterized by an eosinophilic infiltrate in the esophagus and is often triggered by allergens or food antigens. It can lead to dysphagia and esophageal narrowing but does not typically present with ulcers. Instead, the hallmark findings of EoE include rings, furrows, and white exudates on endoscopy, and eosinophilic infiltration is seen on biopsy. This is a different etiology compared to CMV infection, which is associated with viral inclusion bodies and ulceration.

questions.text: A 40-years-old patient presented with heart burn and increased salivation. UGE scopy was done and biopsy was taken and is as shown below. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The image provided shows a microscopic view of esophageal tissue. The key feature to observe in the image is the presence of intestinal metaplasia within the esophagus. This is characterized by the replacement of the normal stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus with goblet cells and columnar epithelium, which is typical of intestinal lining. This change is visible as the glandular structures with distinct goblet cells in the lower part of the image, juxtaposed with the normal squamous epithelium at the top right. This pathological change, in the context of a 40-year-old patient presenting with heartburn and increased salivation (symptoms consistent with gastroesophageal reflux disease or GERD), strongly indicates Barrett's esophagus. Barrett's esophagus is a condition where the normal esophageal lining is replaced by metaplastic columnar epithelium due to chronic acid exposure, and it is a known precursor to esophageal adenocarcinoma. Option B (Adenocarcinoma) is incorrect. While Barrett's esophagus is a precursor to adenocarcinoma, the image does not show features of malignancy such as significant architectural distortion, nuclear pleomorphism, abnormal mitoses, or invasion, which would be present in adenocarcinoma. The glands, while abnormal for the esophagus, appear relatively organized and without clear evidence of malignant transformation. Option C (Esophagitis) is incorrect. Esophagitis refers to inflammation of the esophagus. While chronic inflammation from reflux can lead to Barrett's esophagus, the image primarily shows metaplastic changes (intestinal-type glands) rather than predominantly inflammatory infiltrates or erosions that would be characteristic of acute or chronic esophagitis without metaplasia. Option D (Squamous cell carcinoma) is incorrect. Squamous cell carcinoma arises from the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus. The image clearly shows columnar metaplasia, not dysplastic changes or malignant transformation of squamous cells. If it were squamous cell carcinoma, one would expect to see nests of invasive squamous cells with keratinization and intercellular bridges.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with PAS positive macrophages?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Whipple disease Tropheryma whippeli, a gram positive Actinomycetes engulfed by macrophages give them a foamy appearance and they stain positive with PAS. Option B- lipid laden epithelial cells Option C- architectural distortion, cryptitis, aphthous ulcer, non caseating granulomas, transmural inflammation Option D- cryptitis, superficial inflammation, pseudopolyps

questions.text: Pathologist examines biopsy from a patient presenting with bleeding per rectum with a past history of intussuption for the past 6 months. Histopathology obtained has been shown below. Identify the Pathology?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hamartomatous polyp. The histopathological findings described, along with the patient's clinical history of intussusception and rectal bleeding, suggest the diagnosis of a hamartomatous polyp. Hamartomatous polyps are benign growths consisting of an abnormal mixture of tissues (such as glands, smooth muscle, and other components) that are typically present in a disorganized manner. These polyps are often seen in genetic syndromes like Peutz-Jeghers syndrome or juvenile polyposis syndrome. Hamartomatous polyps are usually not malignant but can cause symptoms such as bleeding, intussusception, or bowel obstruction. The patient’s history of intussusception further supports this diagnosis, as hamartomatous polyps can act as a lead point for this condition. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Tubulovillous adenoma: A tubulovillous adenoma is a type of adenomatous polyp, which is a precursor to colorectal cancer. While these polyps may present with rectal bleeding, their histopathological features would typically show glandular structures with a mixture of tubular and villous patterns, and they would not appear as hamartomatous growths. Tubulovillous adenomas are more likely to have a higher risk of malignancy compared to the benign nature of hamartomatous polyps. The given histology and patient history do not align with this diagnosis. B. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma of the colon typically presents as a malignant tumor with poorly differentiated glands or cells infiltrating the surrounding tissues. The histology of adenocarcinoma would show signs of invasion into deeper tissues and would likely present with irregular gland formation and atypical cells. However, the patient’s history of intussusception (which is more commonly associated with benign polyps) and the described biopsy findings are more suggestive of a benign lesion like a hamartomatous polyp, rather than a malignancy like adenocarcinoma. D. Juvenile polyposis syndrome: Juvenile polyposis syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple juvenile polyps, which are hamartomatous polyps. However, juvenile polyps tend to occur in the proximal colon and usually present in children or young adults. The patient in this scenario is likely an adult and the focus of the case does not emphasize the presence of multiple polyps typical of juvenile polyposis syndrome. Nonetheless, hamartomatous polyps can be present in juvenile polyposis syndrome, but the diagnosis here fits better with a hamartomatous polyp on its own

choices.text: Backwash ileitis may be associated with Crohn’s disease

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Non-caseating granulomas are present. Crohn’s disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that is characterized by non-caseating granulomas. These granulomas are one of the hallmark features of Crohn's disease and can be found on biopsy of affected areas of the gastrointestinal tract. Non-caseating granulomas are clusters of inflammatory cells, but unlike caseating granulomas seen in tuberculosis, they do not have the necrotic center. They are a diagnostic clue for Crohn’s disease, though not all patients with Crohn's disease will show them. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Pseudopolyps can be seen: While pseudopolyps can indeed be seen in ulcerative colitis, they are not typically a prominent feature of Crohn's disease. Pseudopolyps are formed due to the healing of ulcers in the colon, and while they can be seen in both Crohn’s and ulcerative colitis, they are more characteristic of ulcerative colitis. Therefore, this option does not fully apply to Crohn's disease. C. Backwash ileitis may be associated with Crohn’s disease: Backwash ileitis is a term specifically used in the context of ulcerative colitis and refers to inflammation of the terminal ileum due to the backflow of inflammatory material from the colon. It is not characteristic of Crohn’s disease, which can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus, including the terminal ileum but in a patchy and transmural pattern. Backwash ileitis is associated with ulcerative colitis, not Crohn’s disease. D. Both b & c: Since option C is incorrect, the combination of B and C cannot be correct. While non-caseating granulomas are a feature of Crohn's disease, backwash ileitis is not. Therefore, this option is not correct.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest change in intestine which occurs in Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Aphthous ulcer The earliest lesion, the aphthous ulcer, may progress, and multiple lesions often coalesce into elongated, serpentine ulcers oriented along the axis of the bowel. Edema and loss of the normal mucosal texture are common. Sparing of interspersed mucosa, a result of the patchy distribution of Crohn disease, results in a coarsely textured, cobblestone appearance in which diseased tissue is depressed below the level of normal mucosa

questions.text: Which gene involved in colonic adenoma to colonic carcinoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) P53. P53 is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a crucial role in the progression from colonic adenoma to colonic carcinoma. In the normal sequence of colorectal cancer development, genetic mutations accumulate in the APC (adenomatous polyposis coli) gene, followed by mutations in the K-ras gene, SMAD4, and finally P53. The loss of function of P53, which normally regulates the cell cycle and promotes apoptosis in response to DNA damage, is a key event in the transition from benign adenomas to malignant carcinomas. Mutations in P53 lead to uncontrolled cell growth and tumorigenesis, making it essential in the progression to carcinoma. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: B. Rb: The Rb (retinoblastoma) gene is a tumor suppressor gene that regulates the cell cycle by controlling the transition from the G1 phase to the S phase. While mutations in Rb can lead to cancer, it is not primarily associated with the adenoma-to-carcinoma sequence in the colon. Rb mutations are more commonly implicated in cancers like retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, not the specific progression from adenoma to carcinoma in the colon. C. K RAS: The K-RAS gene is an oncogene that plays a role in cell signal transduction. It is often mutated early in the development of colonic adenomas, and its mutation leads to uncontrolled cell proliferation. While mutations in K-RAS are indeed involved in the development of colon cancer, they occur earlier in the process (in the adenoma stage) and are not the driving force behind the progression from adenoma to carcinoma. The progression to carcinoma is more closely linked to the loss of P53. D. EGFR: EGFR (epidermal growth factor receptor) is a cell surface receptor involved in cellular growth and differentiation. While overexpression of EGFR has been associated with various cancers, including colorectal cancer, it is not directly involved in the progression from colonic adenoma to colonic carcinoma. Rather, mutations in EGFR are typically involved in the later stages of cancer progression and are targeted by certain treatments for colorectal cancer.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are characterized by neoplastic polyps except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not primarily characterized by neoplastic polyps. Instead, it is a hamartomatous polyposis syndrome, meaning that the polyps in this condition are non-neoplastic (benign) growths composed of an abnormal mixture of tissue types. These hamartomatous polyps are typically found in the gastrointestinal tract, especially in the small intestine. While Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with an increased risk of cancer, the polyps themselves are not neoplastic. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: B. Gardner syndrome: Gardner syndrome is a condition characterized by neoplastic polyps, particularly adenomatous polyps in the colon. These polyps can eventually progress to colorectal cancer if left untreated. In addition to these neoplastic polyps, Gardner syndrome is also associated with other tumors, including osteomas and soft tissue tumors, making it a condition associated with neoplastic growths. C. Turcot syndrome: Turcot syndrome is another condition characterized by neoplastic polyps, typically adenomatous polyps that can lead to colorectal cancer. This syndrome is also associated with a risk of brain tumors, particularly gliomas. Both neoplastic colon polyps and central nervous system tumors are hallmark features of Turcot syndrome. D. Lynch syndrome: Lynch syndrome (also known as hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer or HNPCC) is characterized by the development of neoplastic polyps, particularly adenomas, which are premalignant lesions that can progress to colorectal cancer. Lynch syndrome is caused by mutations in mismatch repair genes and significantly increases the risk of colorectal and other cancers, making it another condition that is associated with neoplastic polyps.

questions.text: Menetrier disease is caused by excessive secretion of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Transforming growth factor alpha Ménétrier disease is a rare disorder associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor α It is characterized by diffuse hyperplasia of the foveolar epithelium of the body and fundus and hypoproteinemia due to protein-losing enteropathy. Secondary symptoms, such as weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema, are commonly present. Symptoms and pathologic features of Ménétrier disease in children are similar to those in adults, but pediatric disease is usually self-limited and often follows a respiratory infection. Risk of gastric adenocarcinoma is increased in adults with Ménétrier disease

questions.text: Which of the following gastric polyps are seen associated with familial adenomatosis polyposis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fundic gland polyps. These polyps are commonly seen in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a genetic disorder characterized by the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum, often leading to colorectal cancer if not treated. Fundic gland polyps are generally benign and are found in the fundus of the stomach. In patients with FAP, these polyps occur due to a mutation in the APC gene, and they are considered a characteristic feature of the disease. Although these polyps are usually asymptomatic, their presence can be an indicator of FAP. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Inflammatory polyps: Inflammatory polyps are generally associated with chronic gastritis or other inflammatory conditions, not with FAP. These polyps are typically a response to chronic injury or inflammation in the gastric mucosa, and while they may be present in various conditions like Helicobacter pylori infection or inflammatory bowel disease, they are not a hallmark of familial adenomatous polyposis. B. Hyperplastic polyps: Hyperplastic polyps are also not typically associated with familial adenomatous polyposis. These polyps are more commonly found in the stomach, often as a response to chronic irritation or inflammation, such as from gastritis. While they may occur in the stomach, their presence is not a feature of FAP. D. Adenomatous polyps: While adenomatous polyps are the main type of polyps seen in FAP, they are not typically found in the stomach. Adenomatous polyps are primarily seen in the colon and are the polyps that carry a risk of transforming into colorectal cancer in FAP. In the context of the stomach, fundic gland polyps are more characteristic of FAP, not adenomatous polyps.

questions.text: Most specific marker for GIST
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) DOG1 The correct answer is C. DOG1. DOG1 (Discovered On GIST-1) is the most specific marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs). While cKIT (CD117) is a common marker, DOG1 has been shown to be more sensitive and specific, especially in cases where cKIT expression is absent or reduced. DOG1 is a transmembrane protein that is highly expressed in GISTs and serves as an excellent marker for diagnosing these tumors. It is used to identify GISTs, particularly when other markers, like cKIT, are less reliable or negative. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. cKIT (CD117): cKIT (CD117) is a receptor tyrosine kinase that is commonly used to diagnose GISTs and is one of the first markers to consider. While it is a reliable marker for GISTs, especially in 80-95% of cases, it is not as specific as DOG1. Some GISTs may lack cKIT expression, and in such cases, DOG1 remains positive, making it a more specific marker. B. CD117: This option is the same as cKIT (as mentioned above), and it shares the same reasoning. CD117 (cKIT) is a useful marker, but it is less specific than DOG1, and there are cases where GISTs may not express cKIT. Therefore, DOG1 is preferred when cKIT is negative or ambiguous. D. Desmin: Desmin is a muscle-specific marker and is not specific for GISTs. It is more commonly used to identify muscle tumors, such as rhabdomyosarcomas. It is not associated with GISTs and is therefore incorrect in this context.

questions.text: Microdeletion leading to instability of DNA, causing the cell to undergo degeneration is seen as a marker in which cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Colon cancer The correct answer is A. Colon cancer. A key feature of colon cancer, especially in the context of microsatellite instability (MSI), is the presence of microdeletions or microsatellite instability. This instability is due to defects in the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) system. When the MMR system is impaired, such as in Lynch syndrome (hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, or HNPCC), DNA errors accumulate during cell division, leading to the instability of microsatellite regions in the DNA. This instability can cause the cell to undergo degeneration, making it a hallmark of certain colon cancers, particularly those with MSI-H (high microsatellite instability). Explanation for Incorrect Answers: B. Breast cancer: Breast cancer is a heterogeneous disease with multiple genetic mutations contributing to its development. While BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations are common in hereditary breast cancer, microsatellite instability is not a major mechanism of instability in most breast cancers. Therefore, microdeletions leading to instability of DNA causing degeneration are not typically associated with breast cancer. C. Small cell lung cancer: Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a highly aggressive cancer, but its hallmark is chromosomal deletions and oncogene amplification, rather than microsatellite instability. SCLC is usually driven by p53 mutations and RB1 inactivation, not by the type of DNA instability seen in colon cancer. Therefore, SCLC is not typically associated with microsatellite instability or microdeletions. D. Melanoma: Melanoma, a skin cancer, is primarily driven by mutations in the BRAF gene and other molecular pathways such as NRAS mutations. While melanoma does exhibit genetic instability, it is not primarily associated with microsatellite instability (MSI). Melanoma’s genomic instability is more related to mutations caused by UV radiation, and it does not typically involve the same mechanisms of DNA instability as seen in colon cancer.

Benign looking glands which are Alcian blue positive
Viral inclusions in the epithelial cells

questions.text: A 35-year old smoker presents with severe retro sternal pain which is radiating to neck and worsens after heavy meals occasionally it makes him wake up at night. Upper GI Endoscopic examination does not reveal any mass but a velvety patch in the lower esophagus. Biopsy from the lesion is likely to show
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Benign looking glands which are Alcian blue positive A velvety patch in lower esophagus with the clinical history indicative of reflux suggests Barret’s esophagus. Option B is the histopathological picture best describing the condition. Option A is the description for squamous cell carcinoma. Option B is the description for adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 2-year old is having a long standing diarrhea and steatorrhea. The child is also short in stature and has not gained weight. The peripheral smear and an intestinal biopsy was done and is as shown in the figure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Abetalipoproteinemia: Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare inherited disorder characterized by the absence of apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins (including chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins) due to mutations in the MTTP gene. This leads to malabsorption of fats, causing steatorrhea, growth failure, and nutritional deficiencies. The peripheral smear often shows spur cell anemia, which is a hallmark of abetalipoproteinemia. The biopsy typically reveals foamy appearance of enterocytes with intracellular lipid accumulation. This explains the child’s symptoms of long-standing diarrhea, steatorrhea, and failure to thrive. Incorrect options: A. Celiac Disease: Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals, leading to intestinal damage, malabsorption, and chronic diarrhea. However, the peripheral smear and intestinal biopsy in celiac disease would typically show villous atrophy and an increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes, not lipid accumulation or foamy enterocytes. Celiac disease is also less likely to present with the degree of fat malabsorption seen in this case. B. Whipple's Disease: Whipple's disease is caused by Tropheryma whipplei infection, leading to malabsorption, diarrhea, weight loss, and lymphadenopathy. While Whipple's disease can present with steatorrhea and failure to thrive, the biopsy would show PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria, which is not a feature of this child’s case. Additionally, the peripheral smear in Whipple's disease is generally unremarkable. D. Lactase Deficiency: Lactase deficiency leads to the inability to digest lactose, causing symptoms such as diarrhea, bloating, and abdominal pain after consuming lactose-containing foods. However, it does not cause steatorrhea or significant malabsorption of fats. Additionally, the peripheral smear and biopsy findings would not be consistent with lactase deficiency

questions.text: A portion of large bowel of a young patient is shown below. The patient most likely harbors a germline mutation in which of the following genes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) APC The photograph shows numerous adenomas of the colon, consistent with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), also termed adenomatous polyposis coli (APC). This autosomal dominant inherited disease accounts for about 1% of colorectal cancers. It is characterized by the progressive development of innumerable adenomatous polyps of the colorectum, particularly in the rectosigmoid region. Germline mutations in the APC gene, a putative tumor suppressor gene, are responsible for FAP. Carcinoma of the colon and rectum is inevitable in these patients, and the mean age of onset is 40 years

choices.text: Elongated, serpentine ulcers oriented along the axis of the bowel

questions.text: All are features of Crohn’s disease except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intestinal wall is thinned out: In Crohn's disease, the intestinal wall is thickened due to transmural inflammation and fibrosis, rather than thinned out. This thickening of the bowel wall can lead to strictures and narrowing of the lumen, which is a characteristic feature of the disease. The inflammation in Crohn's disease typically affects the entire thickness of the bowel wall, unlike ulcerative colitis, which primarily involves the mucosal layer. Therefore, "intestinal wall is thinned out" is not a feature of Crohn's disease. Incorrect options: A. Earliest feature is aphthous ulcer: Aphthous ulcers (small, shallow, painful ulcers) are indeed one of the earliest features of Crohn's disease. These ulcers can appear in the mouth as a result of the mucosal inflammation and may be found in the intestinal tract as well. These early lesions are often indicative of Crohn's disease in susceptible individuals. B. Elongated, serpentine ulcers oriented along the axis of the bowel: One of the hallmark features of Crohn's disease is the presence of serpentine ulcers. These are deep, elongated ulcers that run parallel to the long axis of the intestine, which is often described as a "skip" lesion pattern, where areas of normal intestine are interspersed with affected regions. This ulcerative pattern is indicative of Crohn's disease and helps distinguish it from other inflammatory bowel diseases. D. Cobblestone appearance: The cobblestone appearance refers to the characteristic mosaic pattern of the intestinal mucosa seen in Crohn's disease. This appearance is due to the fissures and ulcerations in the mucosa surrounded by normal tissue, creating a "cobblestone" effect. This feature is another important visual clue that aids in diagnosing Crohn's disease.

questions.text: All of the following are epithelial tumors of stomach except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Granular cell tumor: Granular cell tumors are mesenchymal in origin and are not considered epithelial tumors. These tumors are composed of large cells with granular cytoplasm, typically arising in soft tissue such as the tongue, skin, and breast. They are not derived from the epithelial lining of organs like the stomach. Therefore, granular cell tumors do not belong to the category of epithelial tumors, which are derived from the epithelial tissue of organs. Incorrect options: A. Signet ring cell carcinoma: Signet ring cell carcinoma is an epithelial tumor that arises from the gastric mucosa. These cells are characterized by the presence of a large vacuole pushing the nucleus to one side, creating a "signet ring" appearance. It is commonly associated with gastric cancer, especially in the diffuse type of gastric adenocarcinoma. B. Neuroendocrine tumor: Neuroendocrine tumors of the stomach, also known as carcinoid tumors, are epithelial in origin and arise from neuroendocrine cells that are part of the epithelial lining of the gastrointestinal tract. These tumors are characterized by the secretion of hormones and are classified as epithelial neoplasms. D. Undifferentiated carcinoma: Undifferentiated carcinoma refers to a poorly differentiated epithelial tumor of the stomach, meaning that the cancer cells lack distinct features of the tissue of origin. This type of carcinoma is considered an epithelial malignancy, despite the absence of well-formed histological patterns

choices.text: Distended macrophages with PAS positive granules in lamina propria

questions.text: Morphologic features of celiac disease include all, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Distended macrophages with PAS positive granules in lamina propria Biopsy specimens from the second portion of the duodenum or proximal jejunum, which are exposed to the highest concentrations of dietary gluten, are generally diagnostic in celiac disease. The histopathology is characterized by increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy. This loss of mucosal and brush-border surface area probably accounts for the malabsorption. In addition, increased rates of epithelial turnover, reflected in increased crypt mitotic activity, may limit the ability of absorptive enterocytes to fully differentiate and express proteins necessary for terminal digestion and transepithelial transport. Other features of fully developed celiac disease include increased numbers of plasma cells, mast cells, and eosinophils, especially within the upper part of the lamina propria

questions.text: Giant hypertrophy of gastric mucosa similar to brain surface is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Menetrier’s disease Ménétrier disease is characterized by irregular enlargement of the gastric rugae. Some areas may appear polypoid. Enlarged rugae are present in the body and fundus, but the antrum is generally spared. Histologically, the most characteristic feature is hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance and cystic dilation is common. Inflammation is usually modest, although some cases show marked intraepithelial lymphocytosis. Diffuse or patchy glandular atrophy, evident as hypoplasia of parietal and chief cells, is typical

questions.text: Skip lesions of colon with epithelioid granuloma are usually seen with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Crohn’s disease Noncaseating granulomas, a hallmark of Crohn disease, are found in approximately 35% of cases and may occur in areas of active disease or uninvolved regions in any layer of the intestinal wall. Granulomas may also be present in mesenteric lymph nodes. Cutaneous granulomas form nodules that are referred to as metastatic Crohn disease (a misnomer since there is no cancer). The absence of granulomas does not preclude a diagnosis of Crohn disease

questions.text: Gluten sensitive enteropathy is most strongly associated with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HLA-DQ2 While nearly all people eat grain and are exposed to gluten and gliadin, most do not develop celiac disease. Thus, host factors determine whether disease develops. Among these, HLA proteins seem to be critical, since almost all people with celiac disease carry the class II HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 allele. However, the HLA locus accounts for less than half of the genetic component of celiac disease

questions.text: Antigliadin antibodies are detectable in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Celiac disease Noninvasive serologic tests are generally performed prior to biopsy. The most sensitive tests are the measurement of IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase. IgA anti-endomysial antibod ies can also be present. IgG anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies may be detected in patients with IgA deficiency. The absence of HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 is useful for its high negative predictive value, but the presence of these alleles is not helpful in confirming the diagnosis

questions.text: Skip granulomatous lesions are seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Crohn's disease Granulomatous lesions are a key feature of Crohn's disease, a chronic inflammatory bowel disease. In Crohn’s disease, granulomas are often present in the affected bowel, particularly in the transmural layers. These granulomas are composed of clusters of immune cells, including macrophages, that attempt to isolate foreign substances. The presence of non-caseating granulomas (granulomas without necrosis in the center) helps differentiate Crohn’s disease from ulcerative colitis and is considered a diagnostic feature. It is important to note that not all cases of Crohn’s disease will have granulomas, but they are present in a significant proportion of cases. Incorrect responses: A. Ulcerative colitis: Ulcerative colitis, another major type of inflammatory bowel disease, is characterized by continuous inflammation of the colon starting from the rectum and extending proximally. However, it does not typically form granulomas. Instead, ulcerative colitis is characterized by crypt abscesses and superficial mucosal inflammation. The absence of granulomas in ulcerative colitis is a distinguishing feature when compared to Crohn’s disease. C. Whipple’s disease: Whipple’s disease is a rare systemic infection caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract but can involve other organs. While Whipple's disease can lead to intestinal inflammation, the hallmark is not granulomas but rather foamy macrophages within the affected tissues. These macrophages contain PAS-positive material, which is characteristic of the disease. Granulomas are not a primary feature of Whipple's disease. D. Reiter’s disease: Reiter’s disease, also known as reactive arthritis, is an autoimmune condition that typically involves the joints, urethra, and eyes. It is not associated with granulomatous lesions in the gastrointestinal tract. While reactive arthritis may occur after an infection, it is not characterized by the formation of granulomas, particularly in the gastrointestinal tract. Granulomas are not a feature of Reiter's disease.

questions.text: True about Barrett’s esophagus is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Columnar metaplasia: Barrett’s esophagus is characterized by columnar metaplasia, where the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium. This process typically occurs in response to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), where the esophagus is repeatedly exposed to acidic stomach contents, leading to injury and repair. In Barrett’s esophagus, the columnar epithelium may also contain goblet cells, a hallmark of the metaplastic change. This condition is considered a precursor to esophageal adenocarcinoma, making it a premalignant lesion, not benign. Incorrect responses: A. Squamous metaplasia: This is incorrect because Barrett’s esophagus involves columnar metaplasia, not squamous metaplasia. Squamous metaplasia occurs when normal columnar epithelial cells are replaced by squamous cells, often in response to chronic irritation (e.g., smoking or vitamin A deficiency), but this is not the primary feature of Barrett's esophagus. The transformation in Barrett's esophagus involves the reversal of squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium. C. Irreversible: This is incorrect because Barrett’s esophagus is reversible in the early stages, particularly with appropriate management of the underlying reflux disease. If caught early, lifestyle modifications, medications (such as proton pump inhibitors), and endoscopic interventions can prevent progression to dysplasia or adenocarcinoma. However, the changes can become irreversible if the condition progresses and results in dysplasia. D. Not premalignant: This statement is incorrect because Barrett’s esophagus is considered premalignant. The columnar metaplasia in Barrett’s esophagus can lead to dysplasia and eventually adenocarcinoma if left untreated. Regular surveillance via endoscopy is recommended for patients with Barrett’s esophagus to monitor for progression to more severe dysplasia and cancer.

questions.text: Pseudopolyps are features of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ulcerative colitis: Pseudopolyps are a characteristic feature of ulcerative colitis, which is a chronic inflammatory condition of the colon. In ulcerative colitis, areas of active inflammation and ulceration in the mucosa can heal with regeneration of the surrounding tissue, forming pseudopolyps—mucosal islands surrounded by ulcerated areas. These pseudopolyps represent regenerating mucosa but are not true polyps (i.e., they lack a stalk and are not neoplastic). They are often seen during endoscopic examinations of patients with chronic or active ulcerative colitis. Incorrect responses: A. Crohn’s disease: While Crohn’s disease can involve the entire gastrointestinal tract and cause ulcerations and inflammation, pseudopolyps are not typically associated with Crohn's disease. Instead, Crohn’s disease can result in fistulas, strictures, and cobblestone appearance of the mucosa. The inflammatory process in Crohn’s disease is usually transmural, meaning it affects the entire thickness of the bowel wall, which contrasts with the mucosal damage seen in ulcerative colitis. C. Celiac sprue: Celiac disease (sprue) is a disorder of the small intestine triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. It causes villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and lymphocytic infiltration. Pseudopolyps are not a feature of celiac disease. The main pathological finding in celiac disease is atrophy of the villi in the small intestine, rather than the pseudopolyps seen in ulcerative colitis. D. Whipple’s disease: Whipple's disease is a rare bacterial infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It affects the small intestine, and the pathology shows foamy macrophages in the lamina propria, along with malabsorption, lymphadenopathy, and arthralgia. Pseudopolyps are not a typical feature of Whipple's disease. The key pathological finding is the presence of PAS-positive macrophages rather than pseudopolyps.

questions.text: Chromosome associated with familial polyposis colon?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chromosome 5: Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an inherited condition characterized by the development of numerous colorectal polyps that have a high potential to develop into colorectal cancer if untreated. The disorder is associated with a mutation in the APC (adenomatous polyposis coli) gene, which is located on chromosome 5. This gene is a tumor suppressor, and its mutation leads to multiple polyps forming in the colon and rectum. The mutation in the APC gene disrupts normal cell signaling pathways and leads to uncontrolled cell growth, which predisposes individuals to polyposis and, if untreated, to colorectal cancer. Incorrect responses: B. Chromosome 6: Chromosome 6 is not associated with familial adenomatous polyposis. While certain genetic conditions involve chromosome 6, such as some autoimmune disorders, it does not play a role in the development of familial adenomatous polyposis. Therefore, this is not the correct answer. C. Chromosome 11: Chromosome 11 is implicated in other genetic disorders, such as Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) and certain hemoglobinopathies, but not in familial adenomatous polyposis. The APC gene, responsible for FAP, is not located on chromosome 11, making this option incorrect. D. Chromosome 13: Chromosome 13 is associated with conditions such as retinoblastoma and some genetic syndromes involving BRCA2. However, it is not involved in familial adenomatous polyposis. The APC gene mutation responsible for FAP is located on chromosome 5, not chromosome 13, making this choice incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following special stains specifically help to identify goblet cells in a case of suspected Barret’s esophagus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Alcian blue at pH 2.5 The Alcian blue stain at pH 2.5 is highly specific for identifying acidic mucins, which are characteristic of goblet cells. Goblet cells are a key feature of intestinal metaplasia, the hallmark of Barrett’s esophagus. This stain selectively highlights the acidic mucins in blue, making it an essential tool in distinguishing Barrett’s esophagus from other esophageal conditions. The identification of goblet cells through Alcian blue is critical for confirming the diagnosis of intestinal metaplasia, as it aids in differentiating Barrett’s esophagus from normal esophageal or gastric mucosa. Incorrect responses: B. Mucicarmine: Mucicarmine is used to stain epithelial mucins, which are present in various tissues. While it stains mucins, it does not differentiate between acidic and neutral mucins as specifically as Alcian blue at pH 2.5 does. Thus, while mucicarmine may highlight mucin-producing cells, it is not the most specific stain for identifying goblet cells in Barrett’s esophagus. C. PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff): PAS is a general stain for glycogen and mucins and can highlight mucin-producing cells. However, it does not specifically differentiate between acidic mucins of goblet cells and other types of mucins. PAS may show positive results in Barrett’s esophagus but lacks the specificity of Alcian blue for acidic mucins. D. Masson trichrome: Masson trichrome is a connective tissue stain primarily used to differentiate between muscle, collagen, and fibrin. It is not specific for mucins or goblet cells and has no role in the diagnosis of Barrett’s esophagus or the identification of goblet cells.

questions.text: Ulcerative colitis is characterised by all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Brisk Lymphoid Aggregates: Brisk lymphoid aggregates are not characteristic of ulcerative colitis (UC). Instead, they are more commonly associated with Crohn’s disease, which frequently exhibits transmural inflammation with lymphoid aggregates in the bowel wall. UC is primarily characterized by continuous mucosal and submucosal inflammation without the formation of distinct lymphoid aggregates or granulomas. This difference in histological presentation helps differentiate UC from Crohn’s disease. Incorrect responses: A. Mucosal and submucosal involvement: Correctly describes UC, which is limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon. Unlike Crohn's disease, UC does not typically involve deeper layers like the muscularis propria or serosa. This superficial involvement is a hallmark of UC and is a defining feature in histopathological analysis. B. Absent granulomas: Granulomas are absent in UC and are a distinguishing feature of Crohn’s disease. The lack of granulomas in UC is a significant diagnostic criterion that helps differentiate it from Crohn’s disease, where non-caseating granulomas are often present. D. Minimal edema: Incorrect because mucosal edema is a frequent feature of UC. The inflammation in UC leads to swelling and edema of the mucosal layer, which is observed in biopsy specimens. The presence of mucosal edema, along with crypt distortion and crypt abscesses, is characteristic of UC.

questions.text: Early to late adenoma transformation in colorectal carcinoma is mediated by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Activating mutations of KRAS: The transition from early to late adenoma in colorectal carcinoma is mediated primarily by activating mutations in the KRAS oncogene. KRAS is a key component of the RAS-RAF-MAPK signaling pathway, which regulates cell proliferation and survival. Mutations in KRAS lead to constitutive activation of this pathway, driving adenoma progression to a more advanced state. This mutation typically follows the initial loss of the APC tumor suppressor gene in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence and represents a crucial step in the multi-hit process of colorectal carcinogenesis. Incorrect responses: A. Loss of APC: The loss of APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) is an early event in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence. It initiates the formation of small adenomas by disrupting Wnt signaling, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation. While essential for adenoma formation, it does not directly mediate the transformation from early to late adenoma. C. Loss of p53: The loss of p53 occurs later in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence, during the transition from carcinoma in situ to invasive carcinoma. p53 is a tumor suppressor gene that regulates cell cycle arrest and apoptosis. Its loss facilitates malignant transformation and invasion but is not involved in the early-to-late adenoma progression. D. Loss of SMAD4: The loss of SMAD4 is associated with later stages of colorectal cancer development, particularly in pathways related to the TGF-β signaling. This event is more commonly observed in the progression of advanced adenomas or carcinomas rather than the early-to-late adenoma transformation

questions.text: Anti tishue transglutaminase antibody is seen in seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Celiac disease The most sensitive tests are the measurement of IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase. IgA anti-endomysial antibod ies can also be present. IgG anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies may be detected in patients with IgA deficiency. The absence of HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 is useful for its high negative predictive value, but the presence of these alleles is not helpful in confirming the diagnosis

questions.text: A 25-years-old man presents with weight loss, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea. Sigmoidoscopy/colonoscopy reveals mucosal erythema and ulceration extending in a continuous fashion proximally from the rectum. Which of the following pathologic findings would also be characteristic of this patient’s illness?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pseudopolyps This is a question that tests your ability to distinguish between ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn disease. First, you need to figure out which one this patient has. The key clues here are the bloody diarrhea (much more common in UC), the rectal involvement, and especially, the continuous nature of the mucosal damage. Once you’ve figured out that the patient has UC, you need to identify the answer choice that is characteristic of UC. The correct answer is pseudopolyps, which are inflammatory polyps found in ulcerative colitis and not Crohn disease. All the other choices are feature of Crohn disease. Especially diagnostic in the transmural nature of the inflammation, which can lead to the development of fissures-and fistulas. Remember also that although Crohn disease can involve any part of the grastrointestinal tract, it typically does not involve the rectum and is usually found in the terminal ileum and/or colon. In contrast to UC, the lesions are discontinuous (skip lesions).

choices.text: Development of autoantibodies directed against tropomyosin
Development of antimicrobial antibodies that cross react with colonic mucosa
Germline inheritance of the APC gene mutation

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has had increasing lower back pain for 5 years. During the past year she also has had arthritic pain involving the knees, hips, and wrists. A stool sample is positive for occult blood. A pelvic radiograph shows changes consistent with sacroiliitis. A colonoscopy is performed, and she undergoes a total colectomy. The figure shows the gross appearance of the colectomy specimen. What is the most likely underlying mechanism of the illustrated condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Development of TH17 immune responses The segment of the colon shows the diffuse and severe ulceration characteristic of ulcerative colitis. The inflammation shown is so severe that areas of mucosal ulceration have produced pseudopolyps or islands of residual mucosa. Ulcerative colitis is a systemic disease; in some patients, it is associated with migratory polyarthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and primary sclerosing cholangitis. The Pathogenesis of ulcerative colitis is unclear, but is most likely mediated by a T-cell response to an unknown antigen (but not a gut infection), leading to an imbalance between T-cell activation and regulation. The TH17 immune response has CD4+ T cells present in the lesions that secrete damaging substances.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, chronic diarrhea, and weight loss. He is found to have multiple pain and swelling of his joints (migratory polyarthritis) and generalized lymphadenopathy. Physical examination reveals skin hyperpigmentation. A biopsy from his small intestines reveals the presence of macrophages in the lamina propria that contain PAS-positive cytoplasm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Whipple’s disease Whipple’s disease is a systemic disease associated with malabsorption, fever, skin pigmentation, lymphadenopathy, and arthritis. Biopsy of the small intestine typically reveals the lamina propria to be infiltrated by numerous PAS-positive macrophages that contain glycoprotein and rod-shaped bacteria. The organism, Tropheryma whippelii, is a gram-positive actinomycete.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with malabsorption, arthritis, and lymphadenopathy. A duodenal biopsy obtained from this patient is shown. He does not have hepatosplenomegaly. A PAS with diastase stain is found to be positive and diagnostic of this condition. The most likely etiology for this patient’s symptoms is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Whipple’s disease Whipple’s disease. The duodenal biopsy shows expansion of lamina propria by histiocytes, the differential diagnosis for which includes Whipple’s disease, Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare infection, metabolic storage disorders such as Gaucher’s disease and Niemann Pick's disease, and malakoplakia. Crushed Brunner’s glands can sometimes mimic foamy histiocytes. Storage disorders are usually associated with hepatosplenomegaly. Tropheryma whippelii is the causative agent for Whipple’s disease. It usually affects middle-aged white men. Patients sometimes present only with arthritic or neuropsychiatric symptoms. Small bowel is most commonly involved. In addition to aggregates of foamy histiocytes, the lamina propria may show foci of adipose tissue.

choices.text: Expansion of the lamina propria by plasma cells and lymphocytes
Increased CD20-positive lymphocytes within the surface epithelium

questions.text: In a patient suspected to have gluten-sensitive enteropathy, which of the listed endoscopic and pathologic findings would be against this diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Increased CD20-positive lymphocytes within the surface epithelium Gluten-sensitive enteropathy is associated with a distinct scalloped appearance of the mucosa, and is histologically characterized by villous blunting and intraepithelial lymphocytosis. Villous blunting is accompanied by expansion of the lamina propria by a lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and crypt hyperplasia. The intraepithelial lymphocytes are CD3positive and CD8-positive T-lymphocytes. While the duodenal bulb and second portion of the duodenum are the best locations to obtain a diagnostic biopsy, proximal jejunum may also be biopsied to confirm this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man has had a 4-kg weight loss with watery diarrhea and flatulence over the past 8 months. He has had urticarial plaques on extensor surfaces of the elbows and knees and on the upper back for the past month. Some of the plaques have small, grouped vesicles. A biopsy specimen of one of the skin lesions shows neutrophils at the tips of dermal papillae with overlying basal cell vacuolization. Under immunofluorescence microscopy, granular IgA deposits appear at the tips of dermal papillae. The figure shows the microscopic appearance of a jejunal biopsy specimen. More than 20 years later, he develops a T-cell lymphoma of the jejunum. Serologic studies are most likely to reveal antibodies against which of the following molecules?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tissue transglutaminase Celiac disease is complicated by dermatitis herpetiformis in this man. Antigliadin, anti transglutaminase, and antiendomysial antibodies can be detected. The jejunal biopsy specimen shows mucosal flattening and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. Individuals who have HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 are more likely to develop these findings. With a gluten-free diet, the skin lesions resolve in some patients. Antibodies to desmoglein 3, a desmosome protein, are present in pemphigus vulgaris, a vesicular disease of older adults without gastrointestinal tract involvement. Cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies are characteristic for rheumatoid arthritis. Antibodies to double-stranded DNA are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which produces erythematous rashes without vesicles. Antihistone antibodies are most characteristic of drug-induced SLE. Anti-RNP antibodies are seen in mixed connective tissue disease, which has elements of SLE, scleroderma, rheumatoid arthritis, and polymyositis. Antibodies to type IV collagen are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, which does not involve skin rashes.
